metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (eddy covariance system of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2013)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Sidaoqiao superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the lower reaches of the Heihe hydrometeorological observation network from 6 July to 31 December, 2013. The site (101.137° E, 42.001° N) was located in the Tamarix surface, Ejin Banner in Inner Mongolia. The elevation is 873 m. The EC was installed at a height of 8 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), as proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), which represent high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened using a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.12 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. 
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Is the two-source energy balance model suitable for estimating evaporation and transpiration in heterogeneous land surfaces?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the main method for collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems based on automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, or scintillometers?
Do challenges in estimating surface fluxes in arid regions primarily stem from image classification errors, uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, or incomplete energy balance closure?
Disjunctive.Answer: uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences and incomplete energy balance closure

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the observational datasets from oasis–desert systems typically collected, and what are the main components of these datasets?
Concept Completion.Answer: Middle and lower reaches of river basins in arid regions of western China

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure evapotranspiration in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure evapotranspiration in arid regions is the use of an eddy covariance system combined with a high-resolution thermal camera. This method involves obtaining field observations from a boundary layer tower and using thermal images to measure the thermal radiation of cropland. The data is then used to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using models like the Craig–Gordon model.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: long-term observations, eddy covariance system, scintillometer, half-hourly turbulent flux data, automatic weather stations, 10-minute average period, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles

Quantification.Question: What is the sampling frequency used in the eddy covariance system for hydrometeorological observations in this field?

Definition.Question: What is the eddy covariance (EC) system used for in hydrometeorological observations?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is used for measuring turbulent fluxes, such as the exchanges of water vapor, carbon dioxide, and heat between the land surface and atmosphere. In the context of hydrometeorological observations, it provides crucial data about these exchanges which are essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon cycles, especially in complex and heterogeneous landscapes like oasis–desert systems.

Definition.Question: What does the quality control procedure for hydrometeorological data entail?
Definition.Answer: The quality control procedure for hydrometeorological data involves a series of steps including data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This ensures that the data collected from automatic weather stations, such as radiation, soil heat flux, and profiles of temperature and humidity, are accurate and reliable for further analysis and research.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in ecological studies?
Definition.Answer: Partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration is significant in ecological studies because it allows researchers to understand the separate contributions of soil and plant processes to the overall water cycle. This separation is crucial for accurate modeling and management of water resources, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions where water availability is a critical concern.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of measuring energy exchanges in oasis-desert systems differ from those in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis-desert systems, challenges include maintaining ecological balance and addressing issues like river drying and land desertification, with a focus on long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange measurements. In strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, the main challenge is accurately estimating surface fluxes under conditions of incomplete energy balance closure and strong advection, with a significant focus on the temperature difference between surface and air impacting model performance.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in dataset composition and observational parameters between the hydrometeorological data collected in oasis-desert areas and those collected using eddy covariance systems in agricultural regions?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from oasis-desert areas include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and vegetation parameters. They are collected using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. In contrast, datasets from agricultural regions using eddy covariance systems focus on turbulent fluxes and soil heat fluxes, with supplementary data from thermal infrared cameras for detailed temperature measurements of soil and canopy components.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred from the observed patterns of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert systems regarding the impacts of ecological stability and socioeconomic development?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert systems are crucial for understanding their interactions, which significantly impact the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. Long-term observations provide a quantitative understanding that aids in recognizing these interactions, supporting carbon peaking, carbon neutrality, and sustainable development goals.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection methods employed in eddy covariance systems and scintillometers affect the interpretation of energy fluxes and water vapor dynamics in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for data collection provides half-hourly turbulent flux data, allowing for detailed interpretation of energy fluxes and water vapor dynamics in heterogeneous landscapes. This approach helps in accurately estimating surface fluxes and partitioning evaporation and transpiration, crucial for understanding water cycle processes and resource management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the need for processing raw eddy covariance data from 10Hz to 30-minute intervals in hydrometeorological observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The processing of raw eddy covariance data from 10Hz to 30-minute intervals is necessary to reduce noise and improve data quality. This involves steps such as despiking, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. These processes help in obtaining more accurate and reliable measurements by minimizing errors associated with raw data collection.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, and how do these challenges affect data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, and land desertification. These factors complicate data collection and necessitate long-term observations to accurately understand the interactions within oasis–desert systems. Furthermore, the complexity of the environment and the need for accurate, high-resolution data require advanced measurement techniques and robust data processing methods to ensure the reliability of the collected data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the exclusion of certain data, such as those recorded during instrument malfunction or precipitation, affect the integrity and reliability of hydrometeorological datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding data recorded during instrument malfunctions or precipitation helps maintain the integrity and reliability of hydrometeorological datasets by ensuring that only high-quality data is analyzed. This reduces the chances of bias or errors in flux calculations and supports more accurate environmental and atmospheric assessments.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the effects of integrating multiple observational datasets, including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, on understanding oasis-desert interactions in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple observational datasets enhances the understanding of oasis-desert interactions by providing a comprehensive view of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This holistic approach allows researchers to better assess ecological stability, carbon cycles, and sustainable development strategies in arid regions, contributing to informed environmental management and policy.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting hydrometeorological data and flux measurements using an eddy covariance system in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving sustainable oasis development, maintaining ecological security, and supporting socioeconomic development in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in processing and quality controlling the eddy covariance data collected from hydrometeorological stations in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, and hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period. Additional procedures include observing radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model utilize field observations for estimating evaporation and transpiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TSEB model uses ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration, which are validated with observed ratios using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and eddy covariance (EC) system measurements. The soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes are estimated using the TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes are calculated while solving energy balance equations. Soil and canopy component temperatures are calculated from thermal images obtained with a thermal infrared camera.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used for the classification of soil and canopy pixels in thermal imagery for accurate temperature component calculation in evapotranspiration studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The classification of soil and canopy pixels in thermal imagery is done using the maximum-likelihood method, which involves extracting soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures from thermal images. The thermal infrared temperatures are then converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation from the sky, and soil and canopy emissivities. Simulated radiometric temperatures are validated against surface radiometric temperatures calculated from observations by a four-component radiometer.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enabled the detailed measurement of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, along with automatic weather stations, enabled the collection of half-hourly turbulent flux data and other hydrometeorological parameters, supporting detailed measurements in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of high-resolution thermal imaging with traditional meteorological measurements enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures from a high-resolution thermal camera with traditional meteorological measurements allows for better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates, enhancing accuracy in heterogeneous landscapes.

Enablement.Question: What challenges do researchers face when using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, and what methods enable overcoming these challenges?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include image classification errors and atmospheric radiation uncertainties. Overcoming these involves using field observations and validating component temperatures with thermal infrared cameras, enabling improved accuracy in arid regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the eddy covariance system encounter challenges in achieving energy balance closure in strongly advective agricultural areas?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective conditions is particularly challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure of the eddy covariance flux measurements. This is often affected by uncertainties in surface–air temperature differences, which can be dominant due to errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperature.

Expectation.Question: What factors influence the effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: The effectiveness of composite temperature separation in arid regions is limited by factors such as image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance. Errors in derived component temperatures, overestimation of canopy temperature due to soil pixels being counted as vegetation pixels, and ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance are major contributors to uncertainties.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant uncertainty in estimating the latent heat flux in irrigated farmland using the TSEB model?
Expectation.Answer: The higher uncertainty in latent heat flux estimation is due to both the uncertainty of the TSEB model itself and the increased uncertainty in the eddy covariance system, especially when the mean sensible heat flux is low. Image pixel classification errors can lead to improper separation of soil and vegetation temperatures, affecting the accuracy of latent flux estimations.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the methodologies used to ensure data quality and reliability in eddy covariance systems for hydrometeorological observations?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodologies for ensuring data quality and reliability in eddy covariance systems involve several steps: raw data collection at high frequencies (10 Hz), subsequent processing to 30-minute intervals using specialized software like Edire, and applying corrections for factors like coordinate rotation, frequency response, and density corrections. Quality evaluation includes testing for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity, and data is screened to remove errors from instrument malfunction or weak turbulence conditions. These methods are thorough and aim to provide accurate and reliable data, although they require careful implementation to minimize uncertainties.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential for integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations to enhance the understanding of oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations holds significant potential for enhancing the understanding of oasis-desert systems. Remote sensing provides broad spatial coverage and can capture dynamic changes over time, while ground-based data offer high-resolution measurements and validation. This combination can improve the accuracy of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange assessments and provide insights into the interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems. However, the success of this integration depends on resolving technical challenges such as data compatibility and scaling issues, as well as ensuring the calibration and validation of remote sensing data with reliable ground observations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how data quality is assessed for datasets involving eddy covariance systems and flux measurements.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality assessment for eddy covariance systems involves evaluating factors such as atmospheric stability and the similarity characteristics of turbulence. For instance, flux values are screened based on criteria like instrument errors, precipitation influence, data gaps, and weak turbulence conditions. Quality assessment levels are assigned based on stability (Δst) and turbulence similarity (ITC) tests.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand what challenges are faced when using remote sensing data to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in using remote sensing data to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes include accurately partitioning soil and canopy temperatures, handling mixed water vapor and heat fluxes, and addressing the complexity of the landscape which contains different soil and vegetation types. Errors can arise from image classification and atmospheric effects, affecting the accuracy of component temperature estimations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets can effectively capture the dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Capturing dynamics in arid regions involves long-term observation datasets from multiple stations, including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These datasets are complemented by auxiliary data like hydrometeorological parameters, vegetation, and soil data. The use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automated weather stations across various locations provides detailed temporal and spatial insights into these exchanges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used in acquiring hydrometeorological data and turbulent flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems, specifically focusing on the instrumentation and sampling frequencies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods in oasis-desert ecosystems involve the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are observed using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. These data are further supplemented by vegetation and soil parameters.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in estimating surface fluxes and evapotranspiration in arid environments using the TSEB model.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in estimating surface fluxes and evapotranspiration using the TSEB model in arid environments include the difficulty in measuring E and T on the ground and the errors in derived component temperatures caused by image classification errors. These errors vary with vegetation abundance and can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, the strong advective environment in these regions and the uncertainties in the EC system contribute to the complexity of accurately estimating the fluxes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be utilized to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems, and discuss the parameters they include.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis-desert systems, which consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These datasets also include auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature gradients, humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data, collected over a period from 2012 to 2021.
